castGroup.head: servants to the Countess of Rousillon.

castItem.roleDesc: a gentlewoman protected by the Countess

castGroup.head: neighbors and friends to the Widow.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage:
Enter BERTRAM, the COUNTESS OF ROUSILLON,
HELENA, and LAFEU, all in black.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
In delivering my son from me, I
bury a second
husband.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
And I in going, madam, weep o'er
my
father's death anew: but I must attend
his majesty's
command, to whom I am now
in ward, evermore
in subjection.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You shall find of the king a husband,
madam;
you, sir, a father: he that so generally
is at all times good
must of necessity
hold his virtue to you; whose worthiness
would stir it up where it wanted rather than
lack
it where there is such abundance.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What hope is there of his majesty's
amendment?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He hath abandoned his physicians,
madam; under
whose practices he hath persecuted
time with hope,
and finds no other advantage
in the process but only
the losing
of hope by time.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
This young gentlewoman had a father,--O
that
'had'! how sad a passage 'tis!--
whose skill was almost as
great as his honesty;
had it stretched so far, would have
made
nature immortal, and death should have play for
lack of work. Would, for the king's sake, he
were living!
I think it would be the death
of the king's disease.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
How called you the man you speak
of, madam?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
He was famous, sir, in his profession,
and it was
his great right to be so:
Gerard de Narbon.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He was excellent indeed, madam: the
king very
lately spoke of him admiringly and
mourningly: he
was skilful enough to have
lived still, if knowledge could
be set up
against mortality.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
What is it, my good lord, the king
languishes
of?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: A fistula, my lord.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I heard not of it before.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I would it were not notorious. Was
this gentlewoman
the daughter of Gerard de Narbon?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
His sole child, my lord, and bequeathed
            
to my 
overlooking.   I have those
            
hopes of her good that her 
education promises;
            
her dispositions she inherits, which
            

makes fair gifts fairer; for where an unclean mind
            
carries 
virtuous qualities, there commendations
            
go with 
pity; they are virtues and traitors too;
            
in her they are 
the better for their simpleness;
            
she derives her honesty 
and achieves her goodness.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Your commendations, madam, get
from her
tears.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
'Tis the best brine a maiden can
season her praise
in. The remembrance of her
father never approaches her
heart but the tyranny
of her sorrows takes all livelihood
from
her cheek. No more of this, Helena; go to, no
more; lest it be rather thought you affect a
sorrow than
have it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I do affect a sorrow indeed, but I have
it too.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Moderate lamentation is the right of
the dead,
excessive grief the enemy to the living.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
If the living be enemy to the grief,
the excess
makes it soon mortal.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Madam, I desire your holy wishes.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: How understand we that?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Be thou blest, Bertram, and succeed thy father
in manners, as in shape! thy blood and virtue
Contend for empire in thee, and thy goodness
Share with thy birthright! Love all, trust a few,
Do wrong to none: be able for thine enemy
Rather in power than use, and keep thy friend
Under thy own life's key; be check'd for silence,
But never tax'd for speech. What heaven more will,
That thee may furnish and my prayers pluck down,
Fall on thy head! Farewell, my lord;
'Tis an unseason'd courtier; good my lord,
Advise him.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
He cannot want the best
That shall attend his love.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Heavens bless him! Farewell, Bertram. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
The best wishes that can
be forged in your thoughts
be servants to you!
Be comfortable to my mother, your
mistress,
and make much of her.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Farewell, pretty lady: you must hold
the credit
of your father. [Exeunt Bertram and Lafeu.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
O, were that all! I think not on my father;
And these great tears grace his remembrance more
Than those I shed for him. What was he like?
I have forgot him: my imagination
Carries no favour in't but Bertram's.
I am undone: there is no living, none,
If Bertram be away. 'Twere all one
That I should love a bright particular star
And think to wed it, he is so above me:
In his bright radiance and collateral light
Must I be comforted, not in his sphere.
The ambition in my love thus plagues itself:
The hind that would be mated by the lion
Must die for love. 'Twas pretty, though a plague,
To see him every hour; to sit and draw
His arched brows, his hawking eye, his curls,
In our heart's table; heart too capable
Of every line and trick of his sweet favour:
But now he's gone, and my idolatrous fancy
Must sanctify his reliques. Who comes here?
Enter PAROLLES. [Aside]
One that goes with him: I love him for his sake;
And yet I know him a notorious liar,
Think him a great way fool, solely a coward;
Yet these fix'd evils sit so fit in him,
That they take place, when virtue's steely bones
Look bleak i' the cold wind: withal, full oft we see
Cold wisdom waiting on superfluous folly.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Save you, fair queen!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And you, monarch!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: And no.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Are you meditating on virginity?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Ay. You have some stain of soldier in
you: let
me ask you a question. Man is enemy
to virginity;
how may we barricado it against him?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Keep him out.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
But he assails; and our virginity,
though valiant,
in the defence yet is weak: unfold
to us some warlike
resistance.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
There is none: man, sitting down before
you,
will undermine you and blow you up.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Bless our poor virginity from underminers
and blowers up! Is there no military
policy, how virgins
might blow up men?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Virginity being blown down, man will
quicklier be blown up: marry, in blowing him
down
again, with the breach yourselves made,
you lose your
city. It is not politic in the commonwealth
of
nature to preserve virginity. Loss
of virginity is
rational increase and there was
never virgin got till
virginity was first lost.
That you were made of is metal
to make virgins.
Virginity by being once lost
may be ten
times found; by being ever kept, it is ever
lost: 'tis too cold a companion; away with 't!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I will stand for't a little, though
therefore I die
a virgin.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
There's little can be said in't; 'tis
against the
rule of nature. To speak on the
part of virginity, is
to accuse your mothers;
which is most infallible disobedience.
He
that hangs himself is a virgin; virginity
murders itself
and should be buried in highways
out of
all sanctified limit, as a desperate offendress
against
nature. Virginity breeds mites, much
like a
cheese; consumes itself to the very paring,
and so dies
with feeding his own stomach.
Besides, virginity
is peevish, proud, idle, made
of self-love, which
is the most inhibited sin in
the canon. Keep it not;
you cannot choose but
lose by 't: out with't! within
ten year it will
make itself ten, which is a goodly increase;
and the principal itself not much the worse:
away with 't!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
How might one do, sir, to lose it to
her own
liking?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Let me see: marry, ill, to like him
that ne'er
it likes. 'Tis a commodity will lose
the gloss with lying;
the longer kept, the less
worth: off with't while 'tis
vendible; answer
the time of request. Virginity, like
an old courtier,
wears her cap out of fashion: richly
suited, but unsuitable: just like the brooch and
the tooth-pick,
which wear not now. Your date
is better in your
pie and your porridge than in
your cheek: and your
virginity, your old virginity
is like one of our French
withered
pears, it looks ill, it eats drily; marry, 'tis a
withered pear; it was formerly better; marry,
yet 'tis a
withered pear: will you anything
with it?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Not my virginity yet. . . .
There shall your master have a thousand loves,
A mother and a mistress and a friend,
A phoenix, captain and an enemy,
A guide, a goddess, and a sovereign,
A counsellor, a traitress, and a dear;
His humble ambition, proud humility,
His jarring concord, and his discord dulcet,
His faith, his sweet disaster; with a world
Of pretty, fond, adoptious christendoms,
That blinking Cupid gossips. Now shall he--
I know not what he shall. God send him well!
The court's a learning place, and he is one--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What one, i' faith?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: That I wish well. 'Tis pity--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's pity?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
That wishing well had not a body in 't,
Which might be felt; that we, the poorer born,
Whose baser stars do shut us up in wishes,
Might with effects of them follow our friends,
And show what we alone must think, which never
Return us thanks.
Enter Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p:
Monsieur Parolles,
my lord calls for you. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Little Helen, farewell; if I can remember
thee, I
will think of thee at court.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Monsieur Parolles, you were born
under a
charitable star.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Under Mars, I.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I especially think, under Mars.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why under Mars?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
The wars have so kept you under that
you
must needs be born under Mars.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: When he was predominant.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: When he was retrograde, I think, rather.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why think you so?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: You go so much backward when you fight.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: That's for advantage.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
So is running away,
when fear proposes
the safety:
but the composition that your
valour and fear makes
in you is a virtue of a
good wing, and I like the
wear well.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I am so full of businesses, I cannot
answer
thee acutely. I will return perfect courtier;
in the
which, my instruction shall serve
to naturalize thee, so
thou wilt be capable of
a courtier's counsel and understand
what advice
shall thrust upon thee; else thou
diest
in thine unthankfulness, and thine ignorance
makes
thee away: farewell. When thou hast
leisure, say thy
prayers; when thou hast none,
remember thy friends:
get thee a good husband,
and use him as he uses thee;
so farewell. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Our remedies oft in ourselves do lie.
Which we ascribe to heaven: the fated sky
Gives us free scope, only doth backward pull
Our slow designs when we ourselves are dull.
What power is it which mounts my love so high,
That makes me see, and cannot feed mine eye?
The mightiest space in fortune nature brings
To join like likes and kiss like native things.
Impossible be strange attempts to those
That weigh their pains in sense and do suppose
What hath been cannot be: who ever strove
To show her merit, that did miss her love?
The king's disease--my project may deceive me,
But my intents are fix'd and will not leave me. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE II
div2.stage:
Enter the KING OF FRANCE, with letters, and
divers Attendants.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
The Florentines and Senoys are by the ears;
Have fought with equal fortune and continue
A braving war.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: So 'tis reported, sir.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Nay, 'tis most credible; we here receive it
A certainty, vouch'd from our cousin Austria,
With caution that the Florentine will move us
For speedy aid; wherein our dearest friend
Prejudicates the business and would seem
To have us make denial.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
His love and wisdom,
Approved so to your majesty, may plead
For amplest credence.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
He hath arm'd our answer,
And Florence is denied before he comes:
Yet, for our gentlemen that mean to see
The Tuscan service, freely have they leave
To stand on either part.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
It well may serve
A nursery to our gentry, who are sick
For breathing and exploit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
What's he comes here?
Enter BERTRAM, LAFEU, and PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
It is the Count Rousillon, my good lord,
Young Bertram.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Youth, thou bear'st thy father's face;
Frank nature, rather curious than in haste,
Hath well composed thee. Thy father's moral parts
Mayst thou inherit too! Welcome to Paris.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: My thanks and duty are your majesty's.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I would I had that corporal soundness now,
As when thy father and myself in friendship
First tried our soldiership! He did look far
Into the service of the time and was
Discipled of the bravest: he lasted long;
But on us both did haggish age steal on
And wore us out of act. It much repairs me
To talk of your good father. In his youth
He had the wit which I can well observe
To-day in our young lords; but they may jest
Till their own scorn return to them unnoted
Ere they can hide their levity in honor:
So like a courtier, contempt nor bitterness
Were in his pride or sharpness; if they were,
His equal had awaked them, and his honour,
Clock to itself, knew the true minute when
Exception bid him speak, and at this time
His tongue obey'd his hand: who were below him
He used as creatures of another place
And bow'd his eminent top to their low ranks,
Making them proud of his humility,
In their poor praise he humbled. Such a man
Might be a copy to these younger times;
Which, follow'd well, would demonstrate them now
But goers backward.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
His good remembrance, sir,
Lies richer in your thoughts than on his tomb;
So in approof lives not his epitaph
As in your royal speech.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Would I were with him! He would always say--
Methinks I hear him now; his plausive words
He scatter'd not in ears, but grafted them,
To grow there and to bear,--'Let me not live,'--
This his good melancholy oft began,
On the catastrophe and heel of pastime,
When it was out,--'Let me not live,' quoth he,
'After my flame lacks oil, to be the snuff
Of younger spirits, whose apprehensive senses
All but new things disdain; whose judgements are
Mere fathers of their garments; whose constancies
Expire before their fashions.' This he wish'd:
I after him do after him wish too,
Since I nor wax nor honey can bring home,
I quickly were dissolved from my hive,
To give some labourers room.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
You are loved, sir:
They that least lend it you shall lack you first.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I fill a place, I know't. How long is't, count,
Since the physician at your father's died?
He was much famed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Some six months since, my lord.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
If he were living, I would try him yet.
Lend me an arm; the rest have worn me out
With several applications: nature and sickness
Debate it at their leisure. Welcome, count;
My son's no dearer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Thank your majesty. [Exeunt.
Flourish.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I will now hear; what say you of
this
gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Madam, the care I have had to even
your content,
I wish might be found in the calendar
of my past
endeavours; for then we
wound our modesty and make
foul the clearness
of our deservings, when of ourselves
we
publish them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What does this knave here? Get
you gone,
sirrah: the complaints I have heard
of you I do not all believe;
'tis my slowness
that I do not; for I know you
lack not folly
to commit them, and have ability enough
to
make such knaveries yours.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
'Tis not unknown to you, madam, I
am a poor
fellow.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, sir.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
No, madam,
'tis not so well that I am
poor, though many
of the rich are damned:
but, if I may have your ladyship's
good will to
go to the world, Isbel the woman and I
will
do as we may.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Wilt thou needs be a beggar?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I do beg your good will in this case.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: In what case?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
In Isbel's case and mine own. Service
is no heritage:
and I think I shall never have
the blessing of God
till I have issue o' my
body; for they say barnes are
blessings.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Tell me thy reason why thou wilt
marry.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
My poor body, madam, requires it: I
am driven
on by the flesh; and he must needs
go that the devil
drives.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Is this all your worship's reason?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Faith, madam, I have other holy reasons,
such as
they are.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: May the world know them?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I have been, madam, a wicked creature,
as you
and all flesh and blood are; and,
indeed, I do marry that
I may repent.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Thy marriage, sooner than thy
wickedness.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I am out o' friends, madam; and I
hope to have
friends for my wife's sake.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Such friends are thine enemies, knave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You're shallow, madam, in great
friends; for the
knaves come to do that for
me which I am aweary of.
He that ears my
land spares my team and gives me
leave to in
the crop; if I be his cuckold, he's my
drudge:
he that comforts my wife is the cherisher of
my flesh and blood; he that cherisheth my flesh
and
blood loves my flesh and blood is my friend: ergo,
blood; he that loves my flesh
and blood is
he that kisses my wife is my
friend. If men
could be contented to be what they are,
there were no fear in marriage; for young Charbon
the
Puritan and old Poysam the papist, howsome'er
their
hearts are severed in religion,
their heads are both one;
they may joul horns
together, like any deer i' the herd.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Wilt thou ever be a foul-mouthed
and calumnious
knave?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
A prophet I, madam; and I speak the
the truth the
next way:
For I the ballad will repeat,
Which men full
true shall find;
Your marriage comes by dest'ny,
Your
cuckoo sings by kind.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Get you gone, sir; I'll talk with you
more anon.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
May it please you, madam, that he
bid Helen
come to you: of her I am to speak.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Sirrah, tell my gentlewoman I
would speak with
her; Helen, I mean.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Was this fair face the cause, quoth she,
Why the Grecians sacked Troy?
Fond done, done fond,
Was this King Priam's joy?
With that she sighed as she stood,
With that she sighed as she stood,
And gave this sentence then;
Among nine bad if one be
good,
Among nine bad if one be good,
There's yet one
good in ten.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What, one good in ten? you corrupt
the song,
sirrah.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
One good woman in ten, madam;
which is a purifying
o' the song: would God
would serve the world so
all the year; we'ld
find no fault with the tithe-woman,
if I were
the parson. One in ten, quoth a'! An we
might
have a good woman born but one every
blazing star,
or at an earthquake, 'twould
mend the lottery well: a
man may draw his
heart out, ere a' pluck one.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
You'll be gone, sir knave, and do
as I command
you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
That man should be at woman's command,
and
yet no hurt done! Though honesty
be no puritan, yet
it will do no hurt; it
will wear the surplice of humility
over the
black gown of a big heart. I am going,
forsooth:
the business is for Helen to come hither.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Well, now.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
I know, madam, you love your gentlewoman
entirely.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Faith, I do: her father bequeathed
her to me;
and she herself, without other advantage,
may lawfully
make title to as much
love as she finds: there is
more owing her
than is paid; and more shall be paid
her than
she'll demand.

sp.speaker: Stew.
sp.p:
Madam, I was very late more near
her than
I think she wished me: alone she was,
and did
communicate to herself her own words
to her
own ears; she thought, I dare vow for
her, they
touched not any stranger sense. Her
matter was, she
loved your son: Fortune, she
said, was no goddess,
that had put such difference
betwixt their two
estates; Love no god,
that would not extend his might,
only where
qualities were level; Dian no queen of virgins,
that would suffer her poor knight surprised,
without rescue in the first assault or ransom
afterward.
This she delivered in the most bitter
touch of
sorrow that e'er I heard virgin exclaim
in: which I held
my duty speedily to acquaint
you withal; sithence, in
the loss that
may happen, it concerns you something
to
know it.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
You have discharged this honestly;
keep it
to yourself: many likelihoods informed
me of this
before, which hung so tottering in
the balance that
I could neither believe nor
misdoubt. Pray you,
leave me: stall this in
your bosom; and I thank
you for your honest
care: I will speak with you further
anon. [Exit Steward.
Enter HELENA.
Even so it was with me when I was young:
If ever we are nature's, these are ours; this thorn
Doth to our rose of youth rightly belong;
Our blood to us, this to our blood is born;
It is the show and seal of nature's truth,
Where love's strong passion is impress'd in youth:
By our remembrances of days foregone,
Such were our faults, or then we thought them none.
Her eye is sick on 't: I observe her now.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What is your pleasure, madam?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
You know, Helen,
I am a mother to you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Mine honourable mistress.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Nay, a mother:
Why not a mother? When I
said 'a mother,'
Methought you saw a serpent: what's in 'mother,'
That you start at it? I say, I am your mother;
And put you in the catalogue of those
That were enwombed mine: 'tis often seen
Adoption strives with nature and choice breeds
A native slip to us from foreign seeds:
You ne'er oppress'd me with a mother's groan,
Yet I express to you a mother's care:
God's mercy, maiden! does it curd thy blood
To say I am thy mother? What's the matter,
That this distemper'd messenger of wet
The many-colour'd Iris, rounds thine eyes?
Why? that you are my daughter?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: That I am not.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: I say, I am your mother.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Pardon, madam;
The Count Rousillon cannot be my brother:
I am from humble, he from honour'd name;
No note upon my parents, his all noble:
My master, my dear lord he is; and I
His servant live, and will his vassal die:
He must not be my brother.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Nor I your mother?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
You are my mother, madam; would you were,--
So that my lord your son were not my brother,--
Indeed my mother or were you both our mothers,
I care no more for than I do for heaven,
So I were not his sister. Can't no other,
But, I your daughter, he must be my brother?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Yes, Helen, you might be my daughter-in-law:
God shield you mean it not! daughter and mother
So strive upon your pulse. What, pale again?
My fear hath catch'd your fondness: now I see
The mystery of your loneliness, and find
Your salt tears' head: now to all sense 'tis gross
You love my son; invention is ashamed,
Against the proclamation of thy passion,
To say thou dost not: therefore tell me true;
But, tell me then, 'tis so; for, look, thy cheeks
Confess it, th' one to th' other; and thine eyes
See it so grossly shown in thy behaviours
That in their kind they speak it: only sin
And hellish obstinacy tie thy tongue,
That truth should be suspected. Speak, is 't so?
If it be so, you have wound a goodly clew;
If it be not, forswear 't: howe'er, I charge thee,
As heaven shall work in me for thine avail,
Tell me truly.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Good madam, pardon me!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Do you love my son?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Your pardon, noble mistress!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Love you my son?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Do not you love him, madam?

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Go not about; my love hath in't a bond,
Whereof the world takes note: come, come, disclose
The state of your affection; for your passions
Have to the full appeach'd.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Then, I confess,
Here on my knee, before high heaven and you,
That before you, and next unto high heaven,
I love your
son.
My friends were poor, but honest; so's my love:
Be not offended; for it hurts not him
That he is loved of me: I follow him not
By any token of presumptuous suit;
Nor would I have him till I do deserve him;
Yet never know how that desert should be.
I know I love in vain, strive against hope;
Yet in this captious and intenible sieve
I still pour in the waters of my love
And lack not to lose still: thus, Indian-like,
Religious in mine error, I adore
The sun, that looks upon his worshipper,
But knows of him no more. My dearest madam,
Let not your hate encounter with my love
For loving where you do: but if yourself,
Whose aged honour cites a virtuous youth,
Did ever in so true a flame of liking
Wish chastely and love dearly, that your Dian
Was both herself and love; O, then, give pity
To her, whose state is such that cannot choose
But lend and give where she is sure to lose;
That seeks not to find that her search implies,
But riddle-like lives sweetly where she dies!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Had you not lately an intent, -- speak truly, --
To go to Paris?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Madam, I had.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Wherefore? tell true.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I will tell truth; by grace itself I swear.
You know my father left me some prescriptions
Of rare and proved effects, such as his reading
And manifest experience had collected
For general sovereignty; and that he will'd me
In heedfull'st reservation to bestow them,
As notes whose faculties inclusive were
More than they were in note: amongst the rest
There is a remedy, approved, set down,
To cure the desperate languishings whereof
The king is render'd lost.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
This was your motive
For Paris, was it? speak.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
My lord your son made me to think of this;
Else Paris and the medicine and the king
Had from the conversation of my thoughts
Haply been absent then.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
But think you, Helen,
If you should tender your supposed aid,
He would receive it? he and his physicians
Are of a mind; he, that they cannot help him,
They, that they cannot help: how shall they credit
A poor unlearned virgin, when the schools,
Embowell'd of their doctrine, have left off
The danger to itself?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
There's something in't,
More than my father's skill, which was the greatest
Of his profession, that his good receipt
Shall for my legacy be sanctified
By the luckiest stars in heaven: and, would your honour
But give me leave to try success, I'ld venture
The well-lost life of mine on his grace's cure
By such a day and hour.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Dost thou believe it?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Ay, madam, knowingly.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Why, Helen, thou shalt have my leave and love,
Means and attendants and my loving greetings
To those of mine in court: I'll stay at home
And pray God's blessing into thy attempt:
Be gone to-morrow; and be sure of this,
What I can help thee to thou shalt not miss. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage:
Enter the KING, attended with divers young Lords taking leave for
the Florentine war; BERTRAM, and
PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Farewell, young lords; these warlike principles
Do not throw from you: and you, my lords, farewell:
Share the advice betwixt you; if both gain, all
The gift doth stretch itself as 'tis received,
And is enough for both.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
'Tis our hope, sir,
After well enter'd soldiers, to return
And find your grace in health.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
No, no, it cannot be; and yet my heart
Will not confess he owes the malady
That doth my life besiege. Farewell, young lords;
Whether I live or die, be you the sons
Of worthy Frenchmen: let higher Italy,--
Those bated that inherit but the fall
Of the last monarchy,--see that you come
Not to woo honour, but to wed it: when
The bravest questant shrinks, find what you seek,
That fame may cry you loud: I say, farewell.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Health, at your bidding, serve your majesty!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Those girls of Italy, take heed of them:
They say, our French lack language to deny,
If they demand: beware of being captives,
Before you serve.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Our hearts receive your warnings.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Farewell. Come hither to me. [Exit, attended.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: O my sweet lord, that you will stay behind us!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: 'Tis not his fault, the spark.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: O, 'tis brave wars!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Most admirable: I have seen those wars.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I am commanded here, and kept a coil with
'Too young' and 'the next year' and 'tis too early.'

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
An thy mind stand to't boy,
steal away bravely.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I shall stay here the forehorse to a smock,
Creaking my shoes on the plain masonry,
Till honour be bought up and no sword worn
But one to dance with! By heaven, I'll steal away.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: There's honour in the theft.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Commit it, count.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: I am your accessary; and so, farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I grow to you, and our parting is a
tortured body.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: Farewell, captain.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: Sweet Monsieur Parolles!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Noble heroes, my sword and yours are
kin.
Good sparks and lustrous, a word, good
metals: you
shall find in the regiment of the
Spinii one Captain
Spurio, with his cicatrice,
an emblem of war, here on
his sinister cheek;
it was this very sword entrenched it:
say to
him, I live; and observe his reports for me.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: We shall, noble captain. [Exeunt Lords.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Mars dote on you for his novices!
what will
ye do?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Stay: the king. Re-enter KING. BERTRAM and PAROLLES retire.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Use a more spacious ceremony
to the noble
lords; you have restrained
yourself within the list of
too cold an adieu:
be more expressive to them: for they
wear
themselves in the cap of the time, there do
muster
true gait, eat, speak, and move under
the influence of
the most received star; and
though the devil lead the
measure, such are
to be followed: after them, and take a
more dilated
farewell.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And I will do so.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Worthy fellows; and like to prove
most sinewy
sword-men. [Exeunt Bertram and Parolles.
Enter LAFEU.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Pardon, my lord, for me and for my tidings.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: I'll fee thee to stand up.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Then here's a man stands, that has brought his pardon.
I would you had kneel'd, my lord, to ask me mercy,
And that at my bidding you could so stand up.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I would I had; so I had broke thy pate,
And ask'd thee mercy for't.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Good faith, across: but, my good lord, 'tis thus;
Will you be cured of your infirmity?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
O, will you eat no grapes, my royal fox?
Yes, but you will my noble grapes, an if
My royal fox could reach them: I have seen a medicine
That's able to breathe life into a stone,
Quicken a rock, and make you dance canary
With spritely fire and motion; whose simple touch
Is powerful to araise King Pepin, nay,
To give great Charlemain a pen in's hand
And write to her a love-line.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: What 'her' is this?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Why, Doctor She: my lord, there's one arrived,
If you will see her: now, by my faith and honour,
If seriously I may convey my thoughts
In this my light deliverance, I have spoke
With one that, in her sex, her years, profession,
Wisdom and constancy, hath amazed me more
That I dare blame my weakness: will you see her,
For that is her demand, and know her business?
That done, laugh well at me.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Now, good Lafeu,
Bring in the admiration; that we with thee
May spend our wonder too, or take off thine
By wondering how thou took'st it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Nay, I'll fit you,
And not be all day neither. [Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Thus he his special nothing ever prologues. Re-enter LAFEU, with HELENA.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Nay, come your ways.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: This haste hath wings indeed.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Nay, come your ways;
This is his majesty; say your mind to him:
A traitor you do look like; but such traitors
His majesty seldom fears: I am Cressid's uncle,
That dare leave two together; fare you well. [Exit.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Now, fair one, does your business follow us?

sp.speaker: Hel.
King.
sp.p: I knew him.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
The rather will I spare my praises towards him;
Knowing him is enough. On's bed of death
Many receipts he gave me; chiefly one,
Which, as the dearest issue of his practice,
And of his old experience the only darling,
He bade me store up, as a triple eye,
Safer than mine own two, more dear; I have so;
And, hearing your high majesty is touch'd
With that malignant cause wherein the honour
Of my dear father's gift stands chief in power,
I come to tender it and my appliance
With all bound humbleness.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
We thank you, maiden;
But may not be so credulous of cure,
When our most learned doctors leave us and
The congregated college have concluded
That labouring art can never ransom nature
From her inaidible estate; I say we must not
So stain our judgement, or corrupt our hope,
To prostitute our past-cure malady
To empirics, or to dissever so
Our great self and our credit, to esteem
A senseless help which help past sense we deem.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
My duty then shall pay me for my pains:
I will no more enforce mine office on you;
Humbly entreating from your royal thoughts
A modest one, to bear me back again.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
I cannot give thee less, to be call'd grateful:
Thou thought'st to help me; and such thanks I give
As one near death to those that wish him live:
But what at full I know, thou know'st no part,
I knowing all my peril, thou no art.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
What I can do can do no hurt to try,
Since you set up your rest 'gainst remedy.
He that of greatest works is finisher
Oft does them by the weakest minister:
So holy writ in babes hath judgement shown,
When judges have been babes; great floods have flown
From simple sources, and great seas have dried
When miracles have by the greatest been denied.
Oft expectation fails and most oft there
Where most it promises, and oft it hits
Where hope is coldest and despair most fits.

sp.speaker: King.
Hel.
sp.p:
Inspired merit so by breath is barr'd:
It is not so with Him that all things knows
As 'tis with us that square our guess by shows;
But most it is presumption in us when
The help of heaven we count the act of men.
Dear sir, to my endeavours give consent;
Of heaven, not me, make an experiment.
I am not an impostor that proclaim
Myself against the level of mine aim;
But know I think and think I know most sure
My art is not past power nor you past cure.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Art thou so confident? within what space
Hopest thou my cure?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
The great'st grace lending grace,
Ere twice the horses of the sun shall bring
Their fiery torcher his diurnal ring,
Ere twice in murk and occidental damp
Moist Hesperus hath quench'd his sleepy lamp,
Or four and twenty times the pilot's glass
Hath told the thievish minutes how they pass.
What is infirm from your sound parts shall fly,
Health shall live free and sickness freely die.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Upon thy certainty and confidence
What darest thou venture?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Tax of impudence,
A strumpet's boldness, a divulged shame
Traduced by odious ballads: my maiden's name
Sear'd otherwise; nay, worse--if worse--extended
With vilest torture let my life be ended.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Methinks in thee some blessed spirit doth speak
His powerful sound within an organ weak:
And what impossibility would slay
In common sense, sense saves another way.
Thy life 's dear; for all that life can rate
Worth name of life in thee hath estimate,
Youth, beauty, wisdom, courage, all
That happiness and prime can happy call:
Thou this to hazard needs and must intimate
Skill infinite or monstrous desperate.
Sweet practiser, thy physic I will try,
That ministers thine own death if I die.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
If I break time, or flinch in property
Of what I spoke, unpitied let me die,
And well deserved: not helping, death's my fee;
But, if help, what do you promise me?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Make thy demand.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: But will you make it even?

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p: Ay, by my sceptre and my hopes of heaven.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Then shalt thou give me with thy kingly hand
What husband in thy power I will command:
Exempted be from me the arrogance
To choose from forth the royal blood of France,
My low and humble name to propagate
With any branch or image of thy state;
But such a one, thy vassal, whom I know
Is free for me to ask, thee to bestow.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Here is my hand; the premises observed,
Thy will by my performance shall be served:
So make the choice of thy own time, for I,
Thy resolved patient, on thee still rely.
More should I question thee, and more I must,
Though more to know could not be more to trust,
From whence thou camest, how tended on: but rest
Unquestion'd welcome and undoubted blest.
Give me some help here, ho! If thou proceed
As high as word, my deed shall match thy meed.
[Flourish.Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Come on, sir; I shall now put you
to the height
of your breeding.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I will show myself highly fed and
lowly
taught: I know my business is but to the
court.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
To the court! why, what place
make you special,
when you put off that with
such contempt? But to
the court!

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly, madam, if God have lent a
man any manners,
he may easily put it off at
court: he that cannot
make a leg, put off's
cap, kiss his hand and say nothing,
has neither
leg, hands, lip, nor cap; and indeed
such a
fellow, to say precisely, were not for the
court;
but for me, I have an answer will serve all
men.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Marry, that's a bountiful answer
that fits all
questions.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
It is like a barber's chair that fits all
buttocks,
the pin-buttock, the quatch-buttock,
the brawn buttock,
or any buttock.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Will your answer serve fit to all
questions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
As fit as ten groats is for the hand of
an attorney,
as your French crown for your
taffeta punk, as
Tib's rush for Tom's forefinger,
as a pancake for Shrove
Tuesday, a morris
for May-day, as the nail to his hole,
the
cuckold to his horn, as a scolding quean to a
wrangling knave, as the nun's lip to the friar's
mouth,
nay, as the pudding to his skin.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Have you, I say, an answer of such
fitness for
all questions?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
From below your duke to beneath
your constable,
it will fit any question.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
It must be an answer of most monstrous
size
that must fit all demands.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
But a trifle neither, in good faith, if
the learned
should speak truth of it: here it
is, and all that belongs
to 't. Ask me if I am a
courtier: it shall do you no
harm to learn.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
To be young again, if we could: I
will be a
fool in question, hoping to be the
wiser by your
answer.
I pray you, sir, are
you a courtier?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O Lord, sir! There's a simple putting
off. More,
more, a hundred of them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Sir, I am a poor friend of yours,
that loves you.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord, sir! Thick, thick, spare not me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I think, sir, you can eat none of
this homely
meat.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord, sir! Nay, put me to't, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: You were lately whipped, sir, as I think.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord, sir! spare not me.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Do not cry, 'O Lord, sir!' at your
whipping, and
'spare not me'? Indeed your
'O Lord, sir! ' is very sequent
to your whipping:
you would answer very well to a
whipping,
if you were but bound to't.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I ne'er had worse luck in my life in
my 'O Lord,
sir!' I see things may serve
long, but not serve ever.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I play the noble housewife with the time,
To entertain
't so merrily with a fool.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O Lord, sir! why, there't serves well again.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
An end, sir; to your business. Give Helen this,
And urge her to a present answer back:
Commend me to my kinsmen and my son:
This is not much.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Not much commendation to them.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Not much employment for you:
you understand
me?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Most fruitfully: I am there before my legs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Haste you again. [Exeunt severally.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
They say miracles are past; and we
have our
philosophical persons, to make modern
and familiar,
things supernatural and
causeless. Hence it is that we
make trifles of
terrors, ensconcing ourselves into seeming
knowledge, when we should submit ourselves
to
an unknown fear.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Why, 'tis the rarest argument of wonder
that
hath shot out in our latter times.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And so 'tis.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: To be relinquished of the artists,--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: So I say.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Both of Galen and Paracelsus.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: So I say.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Of all the learned and authentic fellows,--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Right; so I say.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: That gave him out incurable,--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why, there 'tis; so say I too.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Not to be helped,--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Right: as 'twere, a man assured of a--

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Uncertain life, and sure death.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Just, you say well; so would I have said.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: I may truly say, it is a novelty to the world.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
It is, indeed: if you will have it in
showing, you
shall read it in--what do ye
call there?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
A showing of a heavenly effect in an
earthly
actor.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
That's it; I would have said the very
same.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Why, your dolphin is not lustier:
'fore me,
I speak in respect--

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Nay, 'tis strange, 'tis very strange,
that is the
brief and the tedious of it; and
he's of a most facinerious
spirit that will not
acknowledge it to be the--

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Very hand of heaven.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay, so I say.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
In a most weak--[pausing]
and debile
minister, great power, great transcendence:
which should, indeed, give us a further use to
be made than alone the recovery of the king,
as to be--[pausing]
generally thankful.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I would have said it; you say well.
Here comes
the king. Enter KING, HELENA, and Attendants. LAFEU and PAROLLES retire.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Lustig, as the Dutchman says: I'll
like a
maid the better, whilst I have a tooth in
my head: why,
he's able to lead her a coranto.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Mort du vinaigre! is not this Helen?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: 'Fore God, I think so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Go, call before me all the lords in court.
Sit, my preserver, by thy patient's side;
And with this healthful hand, whose banish'd sense
Thou hast repeal'd, a second time receive
The confirmation of my promised gift,
Which but attends thy naming.
Enter three or four Lords.
Fair maid, send forth thine eye: this youthful parcel
Of noble bachelors stand at my bestowing,
O'er whom both sovereign power and father's voice
I have to use: thy frank election make;
Thou hast power to choose, and they none to forsake.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
To each of you one fair and virtuous mistress
Fall, when Love please marry, to each, but one!

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I'ld give bay Curtal and his furniture,
My mouth no more were broken than these boys',
And writ as little beard.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Peruse them well:
Not one of those but had a noble father.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Gentlemen,
Heaven hath through me restored
the king to health.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.p: We understand it, and thank heaven for you.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I am a simple maid, and therein wealthiest,
That I protest I simply am a maid.
Please it your majesty, I have done already:
The blushes in my cheeks thus whisper me,
'We blush that thou shouldst choose; but, be refused,
Let the white death sit on thy cheek for ever;
We'll ne'er come there again.'

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Make choice; and, see
Who shuns thy love shuns all his love in me.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Now, Dian, from thy altar do I fly,
And to imperial Love, that god most high,
Do my sighs stream. Sir, will you hear my suit?

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p: And grant it.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Thanks, sir; all the rest is mute.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I had rather be in this choice than
throw
ames-ace for my life.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
The honour, sir, that flames in your fair eyes,
Before I speak, too threateningly replies:
Love make your fortunes twenty times above
Her that so wishes and her humble love!

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: No better, if you please.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
My wish receive,
Which great Love grant! and so, I take my
leave.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Do all they deny her? An they were
sons
of mine, I'd have them whipped; or I
would send them
to the Turk to make eunuchs
of.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Be not afraid that I your hand should take;
I'll never do you wrong for your own sake:
Blessing upon your vows! and in your bed
Find fairer fortune, if you ever wed!

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
These boys are boys of ice, they'll
none
have her: sure, they are bastards to the
English; the
French ne'er got 'em.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
You are too young, too happy, and too good,
To make yourself a son out of my blood.

sp.speaker: Fourth Lord.
sp.p: Fair one, I think not so.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
There's one grape yet; I am sure thy
father
drunk wine; but if thou be'st not an
ass, I am a youth
of fourteen; I have known
thee already.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I dare not say I take you; but I give
Me and my service, ever whilst I live,
Into your guiding power. This is the man.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Why, then, young Bertram, take her; she's thy
wife.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
My wife, my liege! I shall beseech your highness,
In such a business give me leave to use
The help of mine own eyes.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Know'st thou not, Bertram,
What she has
done for me?

sp.speaker: Ber.
King.
sp.p:
Thou know'st she has raised me
from my sickly
bed.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
But follows it, my lord, to bring me down
Must answer for your raising? I know her well:
She had her breeding at my father's charge.
A poor physician's daughter my wife! Disdain
Rather corrupt me ever!

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
'Tis only title thou disdain'st in her, the which
I can build up. Strange is it that our bloods,
Of colour, weight, and heat, pour'd all together,
Would quite confound distinction, yet stand off
In differences so mighty. If she be
All that is virtuous, save what thou dislikest,
A poor physician's daughter, thou dislikest
Of virtue for the name: but do not so:
From lowest place when virtuous things proceed,
The place is dignified by the doer's deed:
Where great additions swell's, and virtue none,
It is a dropsied honour. Good alone
Is good without a name. Vileness is so:
The property by what it is should go,
Not by the title. She is young, wise, fair;
In these to nature she's immediate heir,
And these breed honour: that is honour's scorn,
Which challenges itself as honour's born
And is not like the sire: honours thrive,
When rather from our acts we them derive
Than our foregoers: the mere word's a slave
Debosh'd on every tomb; on every grave
A lying trophy, and as oft is dumb
Where dust and damn'd oblivion is the tomb
Of honour'd bones indeed. What should be said?
If thou canst like this creature as a maid,
I can create the rest: virtue and she
Is her own dower; honour and wealth from me.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I cannot love her, nor will strive to do't.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Thou wrong'st thyself, if thou shouldst strive
to choose.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
That you are well restored, my lord, I'm glad:
Let the rest go.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
My honour's at the stake; which to defeat,
I must produce my power. Here, take her hand,
Proud, scornful boy, unworthy this good gift;
Thou dost in vile misprision shackle up
My love and her desert; that canst not dream,
We, poising us in her defective scale,
Shall weigh thee to the beam; that wilt not know,
It is in us to plant thine honour where
We please to have it grow. Check thy contempt:
Obey our will, which travails in thy good:
Believe not thy disdain, but presently
Do thine own fortunes that obedient right
Which both thy duty owes and our power claims;
Or I will throw thee from my care for ever
Into the staggers and the careless lapse
Of youth and ignorance; both my revenge and hate
Loosing upon thee, in the name of justice,
Without all terms of pity. Speak; thine answer.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Pardon, my gracious lord; for I submit
My fancy to your eyes: when I consider
What great creation and what dole of honour
Flies where you bid it, I find that she, which late
Was in my nobler thoughts most base, is now
The praised of the king; who, so ennobled,
Is as 'twere born so.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Take her by the hand,
And tell her she is thine; to whom I promise
A counterpoise, if not to thy estate
A balance more replete.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I take her hand.

sp.speaker: King.
sp.p:
Good fortune and the favour of the king
Smile upon this contract; whose ceremony
Shall seem expedient on the now-born brief,
And be perform'd to-night: the solemn feast
Shall more attend upon the coming space,
Expecting absent friends. As thou lovest her,
Thy love's to me religious; else, does err.
[Exeunt all but Lafeu and Parolles.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Do you hear, monsieur?
a word with you.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Your lord and master did well to
make his
recantation.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Recantation! My lord! my master!

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Ay; is it not a language I speak?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
A most harsh one, and not to be understood
without bloody succeeding. My master!

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Are you companion to the Count
Rousillon?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
To any count, to all counts, to what
is man.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
To what is count's man: count's master
is of
another style.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You are too old, sir; let it satisfy
you, you are
too old.

sp.speaker: Laf.
Par.
sp.p: What I dare too well do, I dare not do.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I did think thee, for two ordinaries,
to be a
pretty wise fellow; thou didst make
tolerable vent of
thy travel; it might pass:
yet the scarfs and the bannerets
about thee did
manifoldly dissuade me from believing
thee a
vessel of too great a burthen. I have now
found thee; when I lose thee again, I care
not: yet art
thou good for nothing but taking
up; and that thou'rt
scarce worth.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Hadst thou not the privilege of antiquity
upon
thee,--

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Do not plunge thyself too far in anger,
lest
thou hasten thy trial; which if--Lord
have mercy on
thee for a hen! So, my good
window of lattice, fare thee
well: thy casement
I need not open, for I look through
thee. Give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My lord, you give me most egregious
indignity.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Ay, with all my heart; and thou art
worthy of it.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I have not, my lord, deserved it.

sp.speaker: Laf.
Par.
sp.p: Well, I shall be wiser.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Even as soon as thou canst, for thou
hast to pull
at a smack o' the contrary. If
ever thou be'st bound
in thy scarf and beaten,
thou shalt find what it is to be
proud of thy
bondage. I have a desire to hold my acquaintance
with thee, or rather my knowledge, that
I
may say in the default, he is a man I know.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
My lord, you do me most insupportable
vexation.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I would it were hell-pains for thy
sake, and my
poor doing eternal: for doing I
am past; as I will by
thee, in what motion
age will give me leave. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Well, thou hast a son shall take this
disgrace
off me; scurvy, old, filthy, scurvy
lord! Well, I must
be patient; there is no fettering
of authority. I'll beat
him, by my life,
if I can meet him with any convenience,
an
he were double and double a lord. I'll have
no more pity of his age than I would of--
I'll
beat him, an if I could but meet him again.
Re-enter LAFEU.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Sirrah, your lord and master's married;
            
there's 
news for you: you have a new
            
mistress.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I most unfeignedly beseech your lordship
to
make some reservation of your
wrongs: he is my good
lord: whom I serve
above is my master.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Who? God?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Ay, sir.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
The devil it is that's thy master. Why
dost
thou garter up thy arms o' this fashion?
dost make hose
of thy sleeves? do other servants
so? Thou wert best set
thy lower part
where thy nose stands. By mine honor,
if I
were but two hours younger, I'ld beat thee:
methinks,
thou art a general offence, and every
man should
beat thee: I think thou wast
created for men to breathe
themselves upon
thee.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
This is hard and undeserved measure,
my lord.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Go to, sir; you were beaten in Italy
for picking
a kernel out of a pomegranate:
you are a vagabond and
no true traveller: you
you are more saucy with lords and
honourable personages
than the commission of your
birth and
virtue gives you heraldry. You are not worth
another word, else I'ld call you knave. I leave
you.
[Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Good, very good; it is so then: good,
very
good; let it be concealed awhile. Re-enter BERTRAM.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Undone, and forfeited to cares for ever!

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What's the matter, sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Although before the solemn priest I
have
sworn,
I will not bed her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: What, what, sweet-heart?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
O my Parolles, they have married me!
I'll to the Tuscan wars, and never bed her.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
France is a dog-hole, and it no more merits
The tread of a man's foot: to the wars!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
There's letters from my mother:
what the import
is, I know not yet.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Ay, that would be known. To the
wars, my boy,
to the wars!
He wears his honour in a box unseen,
That hugs his kicky-wicky here at home,
Spending his manly marrow in her arms,
Which should sustain the bound and high curvet
Of Mars's fiery steed. To other regions
France is a stable; we that dwell in't jades;
Therefore, to the war!

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
It shall be so: I'll send her to my house,
Acquaint my mother with my hate to her,
And wherefore I am fled; write to the king
Shall furnish me to those Italian fields,
That which I durst not speak: his present gift
Where noble fellows strike: war is no strife
To the dark house and the detested wife.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Will this capriccio hold in thee? art sure?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Go with me to my chamber and advise me.
I'll send her straight away: to-morrow
I'll to the wars, she to her single sorrow.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Why, these balls bound; there's noise in it. 'Tis hard:
A young man married is a man that's marr'd:
Therefore away, and leave her bravely; go:
The king has done you wrong: but, hush, 'tis so. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: My mother greets me kindly: is she well?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
She is not well; but yet she has her
health: she's
very merry; but yet she is not
well: but thanks be given,
she's very well and
wants nothing i' the world; but
she is not well.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
If she be very well, what does she ail
that she's
not very well?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Truly, she's very well indeed, but for
two things.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What two things?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
One, that she's not in heaven, whither
God send
her quickly! the other, that she's in
earth, from whence
God send her quickly!
Enter PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bless you, my fortunate lady!

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I hope, sir, I have your good will to
have mine
own good fortunes.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
You had my prayers to lead them
on; and to
keep them on, have them still. O,
my knave, how does
my old lady?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So that you had her wrinkles and I
her money,
I would she did as you say.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why, I say nothing.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Marry, you are the wiser man; for
many a man's
tongue shakes out his master's
undoing: to say nothing,
to do nothing, to
know nothing, and to have nothing,
is to be
a great part of your title; which is within a very
little of nothing.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Away! thou'rt a knave.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
You should have said, sir, before a
knave thou'rt a
knave; that's, before me
thou'rt a knave: this had been
truth, sir.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
Go to, thou art a witty fool; I have
found
thee.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Did you find me in yourself, sir? or
were you
taught to find me?
The search, sir,
was profitable; and much fool
may you find
in you, even to the world's pleasure and the
increase of laughter.

sp.speaker: Par.
Hel.
sp.p: What's his will else?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
That you will take your instant leave o' the king,
And make this haste as your own good proceeding,
Strengthen'd with what apology you think
May make it probable need.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What more commands he?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
That, having this obtain'd, you presently
Attend his further pleasure.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: In every thing I wait upon his will.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: I shall report it so.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I pray you. [Exit Parolles. Come, sirrah. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
But I hope your lordship thinks not
him a
soldier.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Yes, my lord, and of very valiant approof.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: You have it from his own deliverance.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: And by other warranted testimony.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
Then my dial goes not true: I took
this lark
for a bunting.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I do assure you, my lord, he is very
great in knowledge
and accordingly valiant.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
I have then sinned against his experience
and
transgressed against his valour; and
my state that way is
dangerous, since I cannot
yet find in my heart to repent.
Here he
comes: I pray you, make us friends; I will
pursue
the amity.
Enter PAROLLES.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
These things shall be
done, sir.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p: Pray you, sir, who's his tailor?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Sir?

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
O, I know him well, I, sir; he, sir, 's
a good workman,
a very good tailor.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Is she gone to the king?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: She is.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Will she away to-night?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: As you'll have her.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I have writ my letters, casketed my treasure,
Given order for our horses; and to-night,
When I should take possession of the bride,
End ere I do begin.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
A good traveller is something at the
latter end
of a dinner; but one that lies three
thirds and uses a
known truth to pass a thousand
nothings with, should
be once heard and
thrice beaten. God save you,
captain.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Is there any unkindness between my
lord and
you, monsieur?

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p:
I know not how I have deserved to
run into my
lord's displeasure.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
You have made shift to run into't,
boots and
spurs and all, like him that leaped
into the custard; and
out of it you'll run
again, rather than suffer question
for your
residence.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: It may be you have mistaken him, my lord.

sp.speaker: Laf.
sp.p:
And shall do so ever, though I took
him at's
prayers. Fare you well, my lord;
and believe this of
me, there can be no kernel
in this light nut; the soul
of this man is his
clothes. Trust him not in matter of
heavy consequence;
I have kept of them tame, and
know
their natures. Farewell, monsieur: I
have spoken better
of you than you have or
will to deserve at my hand; but
we must do
good against evil. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: An idle lord, I swear.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: I think so.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Why, do you not know him?

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Yes, I do know him well, and common speech
Gives him a worthy pass. Here comes my clog.
Enter HELENA.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I have, sir, as I was commanded from you,
Spoke with the king and have procured his leave
For present parting; only he desires
Some private speech with you.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
I shall obey his will.
You must not marvel, Helen, at my course,
Which holds not colour with the time, nor does
The ministration and required office
On my particular. Prepared I was not
For such a business; therefore am I found
So much unsettled: this drives me to entreat you
That presently you take your way for home;
And rather muse than ask why I entreat you,
For my respects are better than they seem
And my appointments have in them a need
Greater than shows itself at the first view
To you that know them not. This to my mother: [Giving a letter.
'Twill be two days ere I shall see you, so
I leave you to your wisdom.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Sir, I can nothing say,
But that I am your most obedient servant.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Come, come, no more of that.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
And ever shall
With true observance seek to eke out that
Wherein toward me my homely stars have fail'd
To equal my great fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
Hel.
sp.p: Pray, sir, your pardon.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: Well, what would you say?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I am not worthy of the wealth I owe,
Nor dare I say 'tis mine, and yet it is;
But, like a timorous thief, most fain would steal
What law does vouch mine own.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p: What would you have?

sp.speaker: Hel.
Ber.
sp.p: I pray you, stay not, but in haste to horse.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I shall not break your bidding, good my lord.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Where are my other men, monsieur? Farewell. [Exit Helena.
Go thou toward home; where I will never come
Whilst I can shake my sword or hear the drum.
Away, and for our flight.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Bravely, coragio! [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE I
div2.stage:
Enter the DUKE of Florence, attended; the two Frenchmen,
with a troop of soldiers.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
So that from point to point now have you heard
The fundamental reasons of this war,
Whose great decision hath much blood let forth
And more thirsts after.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
Holy seems the quarrel
Upon your grace's part; black and fearful
On the opposer.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
Therefore we marvel much our cousin France
Would in so just a business shut his bosom
Against our borrowing prayers.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Good, my lord,
The reasons of our state I cannot yield,
But like a common and an outward man,
That the great figure of a council frames
By self-unable motion: therefore dare not
Say what I think of it, since I have found
Myself in my incertain grounds to fail
As often as I guess'd.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p: Be it his pleasure.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
But I am sure the younger of our nature,
That surfeit on their ease, will day by day
Come here for physic.

sp.speaker: Duke.
Count.
sp.p:
It hath happened all as I would
have had it, save
that he comes not along
with her.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
By my troth, I take my young lord to
be a very
melancholy man.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: By what observance, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Why, he will look upon his boot and
sing;
mend the ruff and sing; ask questions
and sing; pick
his teeth and sing. I know a
man that had this trick of
melancholy sold a
goodly manor for a song.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Let me see what he writes, and
when he means
to come. [Opening a letter.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
I have no mind to Isbel since I was
at court:
our old ling and our Isbels o' the
country are nothing
like your old ling and
your Isbels o' the court: the brains
of my
Cupid's knocked out, and I begin to love, as
an
old man loves money, with no stomach.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What have we here?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: E'en that you have there. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
I have sent you a daughter-in-law:
she hath recovered the
king, and undone
me. I have wedded her, not bedded her;
and sworn to make the 'not' eternal. You
shall hear I am
run away: know it before the
report come. If there be
breadth enough in
the world, I will hold a long distance. My
duty
duty to you. Your unfortunate son,
BERTRAM.
This is not well, rash and unbridled boy,
To fly the favours of so good a king;
To pluck his indignation on thy head
By the misprising of a maid too virtuous
For the contempt of empire.
Re-enter CLOWN.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
O madam, yonder is heavy news
within between
two soldiers and my young lady!

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: What is the matter?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
Nay, there is some comfort in the
news, some
comfort; your son will not be
killed so soon as I thought
he would.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Why should he be killed?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p:
So say I, madam, if he run away, as
I hear he
does: the danger is in standing to 't;
that's the loss of
men, though it be the getting
of children. Here they
come will tell you
more: for my part, I only hear your
son was
run away. [Exit.
Enter HELENA and two Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: Save you, good madam.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Madam, my lord is gone, for ever gone.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p: Do not say so.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Think upon patience. Pray you, gentlemen,
I have felt so many quirks of joy and grief,
That the first face of neither, on the start,
Can woman me unto't: where is my son, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p:
Madam, he's gone to serve the duke of
Florence:
We met him thitherward; for thence we came,
And, after some dispatch in hand at court,
Thither we bend again.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
Look on his letter, madam; here's my passport. [Reads]
When thou canst get the ring upon
my finger which never
shall come off, and
show me a child begotten of thy body
that I
am father to, then call me husband: but in
such a 'then'
I write a 'never.'
This is a dreadful sentence.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Brought you this letter, gentlemen?

sp.speaker: First Gent.
Count.
Sec. Gent.
sp.p: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: And to be a soldier?

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p:
Such is his noble purpose; and, believe 't,
The duke will lay upon him all the honour
That good convenience claims.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Return you thither?

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: Ay, madam, with the swiftest wing of speed.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
[Reads.] Till I have no wife I have
nothing in France.
'Tis bitter.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Find you that there?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
'Tis but the boldness of his
hand, haply, which
his heart was not consenting to.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Nothing in France, until he have no wife!
There's nothing here that is too good for him
But only she; and she deserves a lord
That twenty such rude boys might tend upon
And call her hourly mistress. Who was with him?

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
A servant only, and a gentleman
Which I have
some time known.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p: Parolles, was it not?

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p: Ay, my good lady, he.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
A very tainted fellow, and full of wickedness.
My son corrupts a well-derived nature
With his inducement.

sp.speaker: First Gent.
sp.p:
Indeed, good lady,
The fellow has a deal of
that too much,
Which holds him much to have.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
You're welcome, gentlemen.
I will entreat you,
when you see my son,
To tell him that his sword can
never win
The honour that he loses: more I'll entreat
you
Written to bear along.

sp.speaker: Sec. Gent.
sp.p:
We serve you, madam,
In that and all your
worthiest affairs.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Not so, but as we change our courtesies.
Will you draw near? [Exeunt Countess and Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
'Till I have no wife, I have nothing in France.'
Nothing in France, until he has no wife!
Thou shalt have none, Rousillon, none in France;
Then hast thou all again. Poor lord! is 't I
That chase thee from thy country and expose
Those tender limbs of thine to the event
Of the none-sparing war? and is it I
That drive thee from the sportive court, where thou
Wast shot at with fair eyes, to be the mark
Of smoky muskets? O you leaden messengers,
That ride upon the violent speed of fire,
Fly with false aim; move the still-peering air,
That sings with piercing; do not touch my lord
Whoever shoots at him, I set him there;
Whoever charges on his forward breast,
I am the caitiff that do hold him to't;
And, though I kill him not, I am the cause
I met the ravin lion when he roar'd
His death was so effected: better 'twere
With sharp constraint of hunger; better 'twere
That all the miseries which nature owes
Were mine at once. No, come thou home, Rousillon,
Whence honour but of danger wins a scar,
As oft it loses all: I will be gone;
My being here it is that holds thee hence:
Shall I stay here to do't? no, no, although
The air of paradise did fan the house
And angels officed all: I will be gone,
That pitiful rumour may report my flight,
To consolate thine ear. Come, night; end, day!
For with the dark, poor thief, I'll steal away. [Exit.

div2.head: SCENE III
div2.stage:
Enter the DUKE of Florence, BERTRAM, PAROLLES, Soldiers,
Drum, and Trumpets.

sp.speaker: Duke.
sp.p:
The general of our horse thou art; and we,
Great in our hope, lay our best love and credence
Upon thy promising fortune.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Sir, it is
A charge too heavy for my strength, but yet
We'll strive to bear it for your worthy sake
To the extreme edge of hazard.

sp.speaker: Duke.
Ber.
sp.p:
This very day,
Great Mars, I put myself into thy file:
Make me but like my thoughts, and I shall prove
A lover of thy drum, hater of love. [Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Alas! and would you take the letter of her?
Might you not know she would do as she has done,
By sending me a letter? Read it again.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p:
[Reads.]
I am Saint Jaques' pilgrim, thither gone:
Ambitious love hath so in me offended,
That barefoot plod I the cold ground upon,
With sainted vow my faults to have amended.
Write, write, that from the bloody course of war
My dearest master, your dear son, may hie:
Bless him at home in peace, whilst I from far
His name with zealous fervour sanctify:
His taken labours bid him me forgive;
I, his despiteful Juno, sent him forth
From courtly friends, with camping foes to live,
Where death and danger dogs the heels of worth:
He is too good and fair for death and me;
Whom I myself embrace, to set him free.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
Ah, what sharp stings are in her mildest words!
Rinaldo, you did never lack advice so much,
As letting her pass so: had I spoke with her,
I could have well diverted her intents,
Which thus she hath prevented.

sp.speaker: Steward.
sp.p:
[Reads.]
Pardon me, madam:
If I had given you this at over-night,
She might have been o'erta'en; and yet she writes,
Pursuit would be but vain.

sp.speaker: Count.
sp.p:
What angel shall
Bless this unworthy husband? he cannot thrive,
Unless her prayers, whom heaven delights to hear
And loves to grant, reprieve him from the wrath
Of greatest justice. Write, write, Rinaldo,
To this unworthy husband of his wife;
Let every word weigh heavy of her worth
That he does weigh too light: my greatest grief,
Though little he do feel it, set down sharply.
Dispatch the most convenient messenger:
When haply he shall hear that she is gone,
He will return; and hope I may that she,
Hearing so much, will speed her foot again,
Led hither by pure love: which of them both
Is dearest to me, I have no skill in sense
To make distinction: provide this messenger:
My heart is heavy and mine age is weak;
Grief would have tears, and sorrow bids me speak.
[Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE V
div2.stage:
Florence. Without the walls.
A tucket afar off.

Enter an old Widow of Florence, DIANA, VIOLENTA,
and MARIANA, with other
Citizens.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Nay, come;
for if they do approach
the city,
we shall lose all the sight.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
They say the French count has done
most honourable service.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
It is reported
that he has taken their
greatest commander;
and that with his own
hand he slew
the duke's brother. [Tucket.] We
have lost our labour;
they are gone a contrary
way: hark!
you may know by their
trumpets.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
Come, let's return again,
and suffice
ourselves with the report of it.
Well, Diana,
take heed of this French earl:
the honour of
a maid is her name;
and no legacy is so rich
as honesty.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I have told my neighbour
how you
have been solicited by a gentleman
his companion.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
I know that knave; hang him! one
Parolles:
a filthy officer he is in those suggestions
for the young
earl. Beware of them,
Diana; their promises, enticements,
oaths, tokens,
and all these engines of lust, are
not the
things they go under: many a maid hath been
seduced by them; and the misery is, example,
that so
terrible shows in the wreck of maiden-
hood, cannot
for all that dissuade succession,
but that they are limed
with the twigs that
threaten them. I hope I need
not to advise you
further; but I hope your own grace
will keep
you where you are, though there were no
further
danger known but the modesty which is
so
lost.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: You shall not need to fear me.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I hope so. Enter HELENA, disguised like a Pilgrim.
Look, here comes a pilgrim: I know
she
will lie at my house; thither they send one another:
I'll question her. God save you, pilgrim!
whither are you
bound?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
To Saint Jaques le Grand.
Where do the palmers lodge, I do beseech you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: At the Saint Francis here beside the port.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Is this the way?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Ay, marry, is't. [A march afar.] Hark you! they come this way.
If you will tarry, holy pilgrim,
But till the troops come by,
I will conduct you where you shall be lodged;
The rather, for I think I know your hostess
As ample as myself.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Is it yourself?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: If you shall please so, pilgrim.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I thank you, and will stay upon your leisure.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: You came, I think, from France?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I did so.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
Here you shall see a countryman of yours
That has done worthy service.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: His name, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Count Rousillon: know you such a one?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
But by the ear, that hears most nobly of him:
His face I know not.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
Whatsome'er he is,
He's bravely taken here. He stole from France,
As 'tis reported, for the king had married him
Against his liking: think you it is so?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Ay, surely, mere the truth: I know his lady.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
There is a gentleman that serves the count
Reports but coarsely of her.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: What's his name?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Monsieur Parolles.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
O, I believe with him,
In argument of praise, or to the worth
Of the great count himself, she is too mean
To have her name repeated: all her deserving
Is a reserved honesty, and that
I have not heard examined.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
Alas, poor lady!
'Tis a hard bondage to become the wife
Of a detesting lord.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
I warrant, good creature, wheresoe'er she is,
Her heart weighs sadly: this young maid might do her
A shrewd turn, if she pleased.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
How do you mean?
May be the amorous count solicits her
In the unlawful purpose.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
He does indeed;
And brokes with all that can in such a suit
Corrupt the tender honour of a maid:
But she is arm'd for him and keeps her guard
In honestest defence.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: The gods forbid else!

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
So, now they come:
Drum and Colours. Enter BERTRAM, PAROLLES, and the whole army.
That is Antonio, the duke's eldest son;
That, Escalus.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Which is the Frenchman?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
He;
That with the plume: 'tis a most gallant fellow.
I would he loved his wife: if he were honester
He were much goodlier: is't not a handsome gentleman?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: I like him well.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
Tis pity he is not honest: yond's that same knave
That leads him to these places: were I his lady,
I would poison that vile rascal.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Which is he?

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p:
That jack-an-apes with scarfs: why is
he
melancholy?

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p: Perchance he's hurt i' the battle.

sp.speaker: Par.
sp.p: Lose our drum! well.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p:
He's shrewdly vexed at something:
look, he
has spied us.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Marry, hang you!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And your courtesy, for a ring-carrier! [Exeunt Bertram, Parolles, and army.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p:
The troop is past. Come, pilgrim, I will bring
you
Where you shall host: of enjoin'd penitents
There's four or five, to great Saint Jaques bound,
Already at my house.

sp.speaker: Hel.
sp.p:
I humbly thank you:
Please it this matron and this gentle maid
To eat with us to-night, the charge and thanking
Shall be for me; and, to requite you further,
I will bestow some precepts of this virgin
Worthy the note.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: We'll take your offer kindly. [Exeunt.

div2.head: SCENE VI
div2.stage: Enter BERTRAM and the two French Lords.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Nay, good my lord, put him
to't; let him
have his way.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
If your lordship find him not a
hilding,
hold me no more in your respect.

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p: On my life, my lord, a bubble.

sp.speaker: Ber.
sp.p:
Do you think I am so far
deceived in him?

sp.speaker: Sec. Lord.
sp.p:
Believe it, my lord, in mine own
direct
knowledge, without any malice, but to
speak of him
as my kinsman, he's a most notable
coward, an infinite
and endless liar, an
hourly promise-breaker, the
owner of no one
good quality worthy your lordship's
entertainment.

sp.speaker: First Lord.
sp.p:
It were fit you knew him; lest,
reposing too
far in his virtue, which he hath
